question: What is the outlook for net interest margins?
answer:
Our outlook for net interest margins (NIM) reflects recent shifts in the interest rate environment and deposit mix:

- Group NIM for Q3'25 was 1.76%, down 4bps quarter-on-quarter and 13bps from the Q1'25 peak of 1.97%. This decline is primarily due to lower benchmark rates, including a 25bps Fed rate cut in September 2025, and a shift in deposit mix<sup>1</sup>.
- For the first nine months of 2025 (9M'25), NIM averaged 1.84%, which is 9bps lower year-on-year, reflecting the impact of lower benchmark rates<sup>1</sup>.
- In H1'25, NIM was 1.88%, 6bps lower year-on-year, with Q2'25 at 1.80% (down 17bps quarter-on-quarter), mainly due to lower IIS recoveries and higher central bank placements<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- Management estimates that a -25bps parallel movement in interest rates would have a P&L impact of approximately AED 200 million if no offsetting action is taken<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.

While NIMs have moderated from their 2024 highs, our strong volume growth and disciplined pricing continue to support resilient net interest income. The outlook remains sensitive to further changes in benchmark rates and deposit mix, with additional rate cuts anticipated into 2026<sup>1</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Q3 2025 Earnings Presentation p. 11](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3038#page=11)  
<sup>2</sup> [Q2 2025 Earnings Presentation p. 11](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1707#page=11)  
<sup>3</sup> [Investor Presentation Q2 2025 p. 25](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/2711#page=25)

question: who is the CEO and what is their background?
answer:
Our current Group Chief Executive Officer (CEO) is Hana Al Rostamani.

Background:
- Appointed as FAB’s Group CEO in January 2021
- Over 25 years of experience in banking and finance
- First female CEO of a UAE-based bank
- Previously served as Deputy Group CEO and Group Head of Personal Banking at FAB, where she led the transformation of the consumer bank
- Held senior leadership roles at First Gulf Bank, Citibank, and AW Rostamani Group before joining FAB
- Chairs the Principals Group of the Net-Zero Banking Alliance and previously chaired the Global Council on Clean Energy for the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals
- Serves on several boards, including Buna (Arab Monetary Fund’s cross-border payment system), Institute of International Finance (IIF), International Institute for Management Development (IMD), and the Executive Board of the US-UAE Business Council
- Holds a Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration and a Master’s degree in Information Management from George Washington University, USA
- UAE national, married, and mother of three children<sup>1</sup>

References:
<sup>1</sup> [Euroland Company Fact sheet](https://www.bankfab.com/en-ae/about-fab/investor-relations)

question: How has FAB’s performance evolved over the past few years?
answer:
FAB’s performance over the past few years has shown strong, consistent growth across all major financial and operational metrics:

**2025 (Year-to-date, as of Q3):**
- Net profit for the first nine months reached AED 16.02 billion, up 24% year-on-year, already surpassing the full-year 2024 net profit<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.
- Operating income rose 16% to AED 27.65 billion, driven by both net interest income (up 2% to AED 14.96 billion) and a surge in non-interest income (up 37% to AED 12.7 billion, now 46% of Group revenue)<sup>2</sup>.
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) reached 20.0%, well above our medium-term guidance of >16%<sup>2</sup>.
- Total assets grew 14% year-to-date to AED 1.38 trillion, with loans and advances up 13% and customer deposits up 8%<sup>2</sup>.
- Cost-to-income ratio improved to 22.0%, reflecting continued efficiency gains<sup>2</sup>.
- Our international franchise contributed 17% of Group revenue, with international loans and deposits rising 23% and 18% year-to-date, respectively<sup>2</sup>.

**2024 (Full Year):**
- Net profit after tax was AED 17.1 billion, up 4% year-on-year, despite the introduction of UAE corporate tax<sup>3</sup>.
- Profit before tax grew 13% to AED 19.9 billion<sup>3</sup>.
- Operating income increased 15% to AED 31.6 billion, with net interest income up 8% to AED 19.6 billion and net interest margin expanding to 1.93%<sup>3</sup>.
- RoTE stood at 16.8%, in line with our >16% guidance<sup>3</sup>.
- Total assets crossed AED 1.2 trillion<sup>3</sup>.

**2023 and Earlier:**
- The strong momentum in 2024 was a continuation of several years of double-digit growth in both revenue and profits, supported by business diversification, international expansion, and disciplined cost and risk management<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.
- For Q1 2024, net profit was AED 4.2 billion (+6% yoy), with total income at AED 8.0 billion (+18% yoy), and RoTE at 17.4%<sup>4</sup>.
- Cost-to-income ratio improved to historical lows, reflecting operational efficiency gains<sup>4</sup>.

**Strategic and Operational Highlights:**
- All business divisions delivered record revenues in 2025, with the international franchise playing an increasing role in growth<sup>2</sup>.
- Our balance sheet remains robust, with a CET1 ratio of 13.7% and a liquidity coverage ratio of 158% as of September 2025<sup>2</sup>.
- We continue to invest in technology, AI, and digital transformation, driving productivity and customer experience<sup>2</sup>.
- FAB’s ESG leadership is recognized with top ratings (MSCI AA, Refinitiv ESG Score top 6% globally), and sustainable finance commitments are on track<sup>2</sup>.

**Summary Table: Key Metrics Evolution**

| Metric                     | 2023           | 2024           | 9M 2025         |
|----------------------------|----------------|----------------|-----------------|
| Net Profit (AED bn)        | 16.4           | 17.1           | 16.02           |
| Operating Income (AED bn)  | 27.5           | 31.6           | 27.65           |
| RoTE (%)                   | 16.5           | 16.8           | 20.0            |
| Total Assets (AED tn)      | 1.20           | 1.24           | 1.38            |
| Cost-to-Income Ratio (%)   | ~24.5          | ~24.0          | 22.0            |

FAB’s performance trajectory demonstrates robust, broad-based growth, strong returns, and operational excellence, positioning us well for continued value creation.

question: How is FAB progressing on sustainability and ESG?
answer:
FAB is making strong progress on sustainability and ESG, with a clear strategy, robust governance, and ambitious targets:

**Strategic Commitments & Progress**
- We have committed to lend, invest, and facilitate AED 500 billion (USD 136 billion) in sustainable and transition financing by 2030. By the end of 2024, we had already achieved 53% of this goal<sup>1</sup>.
- Our ESG strategy is built on three pillars:
  - Transitioning to a low-carbon future (net zero for our own operations by 2030, and financed emissions by 2050)
  - Transforming our governance model (including a dedicated Board Risk & ESG Committee)
  - Capitalising on our social responsibility (with targets for diversity, inclusion, and Emiratisation)<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- In 2024, we introduced a comprehensive Group Climate Risk Policy and Group Climate Risk Framework, including climate risk scoring and stress testing<sup>1</sup>.

**Governance & Oversight**
- ESG principles are fully integrated into our governance framework, with dedicated committees such as the Board Risk and ESG Committee (BRESGC), Group ESG Committee (G-ESGC), and ESG and Sustainable Finance Committee (ESG-SFC) overseeing strategy, risk, and performance<sup>4</sup><sup>5</sup>.
- In 2024, these committees reviewed progress against ESG targets, approved updates to frameworks and policies, and ensured ESG topics are regularly addressed at the highest levels<sup>5</sup>.

**Sustainable Finance & Reporting**
- Our Sustainable Finance Framework guides the classification and monitoring of sustainable and transition finance. All ESG deals are tagged in our systems, with monthly reporting and annual public disclosures in our Sustainable Finance and ESG Reports<sup>6</sup>.
- We have a dedicated ESG and Sustainable Finance Committee to assess and classify all transactions for ESG compliance before credit approval<sup>7</sup>.

**Capacity Building & Culture**
- In 2024, we delivered over 27,000 hours of ESG training to employees (averaging four hours per employee), and 99% of staff received anti-corruption training<sup>8</sup>.
- ESG awareness and capacity-building are embedded across all levels, including senior leadership, to drive cultural transformation<sup>9</sup>.

**Recognition & Transparency**
- FAB is included in major ESG indices such as MSCI Emerging Markets ESG Leaders and FTSE4Good Emerging Market, and maintains strong ESG ratings (Sustainalytics: 16.9, MSCI: AA, Refinitiv: 79 as of September 2025)<sup>10</sup>.
- We publish annual ESG, Sustainable Finance, and Equator Principles reports, aligned with international standards like GRI, ICMA, and the Net Zero Banking Alliance<sup>11</sup>.

question: any comments on the weakening dollar by the c-suite
answer:
Our C-suite has addressed the impact of a weakening dollar on several occasions. Here are the key comments:

- We do not engage in material FX position-taking on the US dollar. Given the AED is pegged to the USD, our FX principal risk remains within appetite, and there is no real expansion of FX risk across the board. As a result, the weakening dollar does not have a direct correlation to our revenue stream<sup>1</sup>.
- Regarding deposit gathering in international branches, management does not see a link between the weakening dollar and our ability to attract deposits. Deposit growth is driven more by commercial flows, business activity, and individuals building cash balances. Our AA- rating also attracts deposits as a flight to safety during volatile times<sup>2</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Q1 2025 Earnings Call Transcript p. 11](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/741#page=11)  
<sup>2</sup> [Q1 2025 Earnings Call Transcript p. 19](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/741#page=19)

question: How is FAB leveraging AI and digital innovation to drive growth?
answer:
We are leveraging AI and digital innovation as core drivers of our growth strategy, embedding advanced technologies across our operations, products, and customer experience. Here’s how:

- We have embedded AI deeply into our operations, with innovations such as our foundational Agentic AI platform, the rollout of Microsoft 365 Copilot to all employees, and the launch of AI-powered onboarding and credit analytics. These initiatives have delivered measurable improvements in efficiency and service quality. Tools like the Board AI Observer, Voice Concierge, and AI-powered planning tools are already delivering real impact across the Group<sup>1</sup>.
- Our AI Innovation Hub, launched in partnership with Microsoft, is accelerating the adoption of generative AI, intelligent automation, and machine learning. This hub focuses on innovation, sustainability, and customer experience, and is driving product enhancement, personalisation, unique AI risk models, and new digital solutions<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- We are deploying GenAI-powered tools such as Voice Concierge, intelligent email routing, and real-time fraud detection to redefine customer service and deliver seamless, zero-touch experiences<sup>4</sup>.
- Our digital transformation is evident, with 96% of all transactions now conducted digitally and a 27% year-on-year increase in digitally registered users. We have also launched digital product bundles and enhanced our mobile app, which has won awards for user experience and innovation<sup>5</sup><sup>6</sup>.
- We are modernising our technology infrastructure, expanding cloud adoption, and consolidating our digital assets. Over 80% of our projects are now aligned with our target state architecture, enabling faster rollout of digitally enabled services and easier API-based integration with partners and customers<sup>7</sup><sup>8</sup>.
- Our Research and Innovation Centre (FABRIC) is driving exploration and pilot testing of blockchain, crypto, and fintech partnerships, further strengthening our position within the fintech ecosystem<sup>8</sup>.
- We have also launched an AI Academy in collaboration with Microsoft to build internal capabilities and accelerate the deployment of AI and GenAI solutions across the Group<sup>9</sup>.

question: summarize the CFO comments from the latest Q3 2025 earnings
answer:
Here’s a summary of the CFO’s comments from our latest Q3 2025 earnings:

- We delivered strong underlying operating momentum across all business segments, with Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) reaching 20%, well above our medium-term guidance of over 16%.
- Group revenue grew to AED 27.65 billion, up 16% year-on-year, supported by diversified growth across all divisions, resilient margins, and an improved revenue mix.
- Our balance sheet continues to expand at scale, with total assets at AED 1.38 trillion, underpinned by our AA- credit rating.
- All divisions posted double-digit revenue growth, supported by strong business volumes, including a 49% increase in assets under management.
- Our international franchise delivered double-digit growth in loans and deposits, contributing 17% to group revenue, reflecting the strength of our network across more than 20 markets.
- On Net Interest Margins (NIMs), the main quarter-on-quarter movement was due to a shift from CASA to fixed deposits, marginally increasing the cost of funds. NIM is expected to be in the 1.80%–1.85% range for the remainder of the year.
- We remain well positioned to sustain momentum into the final quarter, with continued strategic execution in lending, deposits, and client acquisitions, supported by deeper engagement across investment banking, wholesale, and personal banking.

question: how is NIM developing during the last 2 years
answer:
Our Net Interest Margin (NIM) has shown a clear pattern over the last two years:

**2023 – Early 2024: Strong Upward Trend**
- Q1'23: 1.74%
- Q2'23: 1.73%
- Q3'23: 1.81%
- Q4'23: 1.89%
- Q1'24: 1.92%
- Q2'24: 1.96%
- H1'24 average: 1.94% (up 20bps year-on-year)<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>

**Late 2024 – 2025: NIM Peaks, Then Declines**
- Q3'24: 1.89%
- Q4'24: 1.93%
- Q1'25: 1.97% (highest point in the period)
- Q2'25: 1.80% (down 17bps quarter-on-quarter)
- Q3'25: 1.76%
- 9M'25 average: 1.84% (down 9bps year-on-year)<sup>4</sup><sup>5</sup><sup>6</sup>

**Summary of the trend:**
- NIM increased steadily from early 2023 through Q1 2025, peaking at 1.97% in Q1 2025.
- From Q2 2025, NIM declined, reaching 1.80% in Q2 2025 and 1.76% in Q3 2025.
- The recent decline is mainly due to lower benchmark rates and a shift in deposit mix, with management highlighting the impact of US rate cuts and seasonal factors.

question: What are the main drivers behind FAB’s growth strategy?
answer:
The main drivers behind FAB’s growth strategy are:

- **Diversification of Revenue Streams:** We focus on broad-based growth across all business segments—Investment Banking & Markets, Wholesale Banking, and Personal, Business, Wealth & Privileged Client Banking. This diversification is reflected in double-digit revenue growth, with international operations now contributing 17% of Group revenue in 9M 2025<sup>1</sup>.
- **International Expansion:** Our global footprint spans 20 markets, with significant growth in loans and deposits in the UK, France, Switzerland, and Saudi Arabia. We continue to strengthen our position as a leading corridor bank, connecting clients to global trade and investment flows<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- **Client-Centric Solutions:** Growth is driven by strong client activity, new client acquisitions, and tailored solutions across segments. We remain committed to enhancing customer engagement and broadening relationships, especially in wealth management and private banking, where AUMs rose 61% year-on-year in H1 2025<sup>2</sup>.
- **Technology and AI Adoption:** We are accelerating our AI journey, embedding advanced analytics and GenAI-powered tools across operations. Innovations such as the Board AI Observer, Voice Concierge, and real-time fraud detection are transforming both decision-making and customer service<sup>2</sup>.
- **Digitisation and Operational Excellence:** 96% of all transactions are now conducted digitally. We launched digital product bundles and elite propositions to simplify and automate customer journeys, driving efficiency and enhancing the customer experience<sup>4</sup>.
- **Strategic Presence and Connectivity:** Our extensive network enables us to capture trade, investment, and liquidity flows across MENA and beyond, supporting the UAE’s economic diversification agenda and boosting multilateral cooperation<sup>4</sup>.
- **Sustainability Leadership:** We embed ESG factors into our business strategy, governance, and risk management, and are committed to facilitating over AED 500 billion in sustainable and transition financing by 2030<sup>4</sup>.
- **Strong Capital, Liquidity, and Risk Profile:** Our robust balance sheet, high-quality risk profile, and disciplined risk management underpin our ability to deliver sustainable growth and returns<sup>1</sup><sup>4</sup>.

References:

question: What were FAB’s latest results?
answer:
Our latest results for the first nine months of 2025 (9M’25) show record performance:

- Net profit reached AED 16.02 billion, up 24% year-on-year
- Operating income (Group revenue) rose 16% year-on-year to AED 27.65 billion
- Q3’25 net profit was AED 5.39 billion, up 21% year-on-year
- Q3’25 operating income was AED 9.34 billion, up 14% year-on-year
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) for 9M’25 stood at 20.0%
- Total assets increased to AED 1.38 trillion, up 14% year-to-date
- Net interest income for 9M’25 grew 2% year-on-year to AED 14.96 billion
- Non-interest income surged 37% year-on-year to AED 12.70 billion, now 46% of Group revenue
- Loans, advances, and Islamic financing (net) grew 13% year-to-date to AED 596 billion
- Customer deposits increased 8% year-to-date to AED 848 billion
- Cost-to-income ratio improved to 22.0%
- Net impairment charges were AED 2.33 billion for 9M’25, down 18% year-on-year (cost of risk: 55 bps)
- Capital and liquidity remain strong: CET1 ratio at 13.7%, Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) at 158%
- International operations contributed 17% of Group revenue, with international loans and deposits up 23% and 18% year-to-date, respectively

All business divisions delivered record revenue, and the Group is well on track to meet its full-year 2025 financial guidance<sup>1</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Euroland Company Fact sheet](https://www.bankfab.com/en-ae/about-fab/investor-relations)

question: What is the outlook for net interest margins?
answer:
Our outlook for net interest margins (NIM) reflects recent market dynamics and interest rate movements:

- Group NIM for Q3'25 was 1.76%, down 4bps quarter-on-quarter, mainly due to a shift in deposit mix. For the first nine months of 2025, NIM averaged 1.84%, which is 9bps lower year-on-year, largely reflecting lower benchmark rates, including the 25bps Fed rate cut in September 2025<sup>1</sup>.
- The NIM trend has shown a decline in recent quarters: Q1'25 at 1.97%, Q2'25 at 1.80%, and Q3'25 at 1.76%. This marks a reversal from the earlier upward trajectory seen in 2024 and early 2025<sup>1</sup>.
- Management estimates that a -25bps parallel movement in interest rates would have a negative P&L impact of approximately AED 200mn, if no offsetting action is taken<sup>1</sup>.
- The outlook for the remainder of 2025 and into 2026 anticipates further rate cuts, which could continue to exert downward pressure on NIMs. The bank expects 2 additional rate cuts in Q4'25 and 2-3 more in FY'26<sup>2</sup>.

In summary, while NIMs have remained resilient due to strong volume growth and disciplined pricing, the outlook is for continued pressure on margins given the anticipated lower interest rate environment.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Q3 2025 Earnings Presentation p. 11](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3038#page=11)  
<sup>2</sup> [Q3/9M’25 Earnings Presentation p. 4, 6](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3038#page=4)

question: How has FAB’s performance evolved over the past few years?
answer:
FAB’s performance has shown strong and consistent growth over the past several years, marked by record profitability, expanding business momentum, and robust returns:

**2025 (Year-to-date, as of Q3):**
- Net profit for the first nine months reached AED 16.02 billion, up 24% year-on-year.
- Operating income rose 16% year-on-year to AED 27.65 billion.
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) stood at 20.0%, well above our medium-term target of >16%.
- Total assets grew 14% year-to-date to AED 1.38 trillion.
- Non-interest income surged 37% year-on-year to AED 12.70 billion, now making up 46% of Group revenue.
- Cost-to-income ratio improved to 22.0%.
- All business divisions delivered record revenue, with international operations contributing 17% of Group revenue and international loans and deposits up 23% and 18% year-to-date, respectively.<sup>1</sup>

**2024 (Full Year):**
- Net profit after tax was AED 17.1 billion, up 4% year-on-year, even after absorbing the impact of the UAE corporate tax.
- Profit before tax increased 13% to AED 19.9 billion.
- Operating income grew 15% to AED 31.6 billion.
- Net interest income reached AED 19.6 billion, up 8%, with Net Interest Margin (NIM) expanding to 1.93%.
- RoTE for the year was 16.8%, in line with our guidance.
- Cost/income ratio stood at 24.3%, reflecting strong operating efficiency.<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>

**2023:**
- FAB continued to deliver double-digit growth in revenue and profits, with a strong balance sheet and robust capital and liquidity positions.
- The bank maintained its focus on diversification, digital transformation, and international expansion.<sup>4</sup>

**Key Trends:**
- Consistent double-digit growth in both net profit and operating income over recent years.
- Strong improvement in efficiency, with cost-to-income ratios declining steadily.
- Increasing contribution from non-interest income, reflecting successful diversification.
- Expansion of international business, now accounting for a significant share of revenue and balance sheet growth.
- Robust capital and liquidity, with CET1 ratio at 13.7% and LCR at 158% as of Q3 2025.<sup>1</sup>
- Continued investment in AI, digital, and technology to drive productivity and innovation.<sup>1</sup>

**Summary:**  
FAB’s evolution over the past few years is characterized by record profitability, strong revenue growth, improved efficiency, and a successful diversification strategy—both in terms of business lines and geography. The bank remains well ahead of its medium-term targets and is strongly positioned for continued sustainable growth.

References:  
<sup>1</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q3 2025 p. 2-6](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=2)  
<sup>2</sup> [Annual Report 2024 p. 14](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/436#page=14)  
<sup>3</sup> [Q4 2024 PR p. 3](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/553#page=3)  
<sup>4</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q1 2024 p. 3](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1211#page=3)

question: ما هي مؤشرات الأداء الرئيسية التشغيلية والمالية التي تم تسليط الضوء عليها في آخر تحديث أو نتائج؟
answer:
في آخر نتائجنا (تسعة أشهر 2025)، أبرز مؤشرات الأداء الرئيسية التشغيلية والمالية التي تم تسليط الضوء عليها هي:

**المؤشرات المالية:**
- صافي الربح: 16.02 مليار درهم، بنمو 24% على أساس سنوي (الربع الثالث فقط: 5.39 مليار درهم، +21% سنويًا)<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>
- الدخل التشغيلي (الإيرادات): 27.65 مليار درهم، بزيادة 16% سنويًا (الربع الثالث فقط: 9.34 مليار درهم، +14% سنويًا)<sup>2</sup>
- صافي دخل الفوائد: 14.96 مليار درهم، +2% سنويًا<sup>2</sup>
- الدخل غير المرتبط بالفوائد: 12.70 مليار درهم، +37% سنويًا، ويمثل 46% من إجمالي الإيرادات<sup>2</sup>
- المصروفات التشغيلية: 6.07 مليار درهم، بارتفاع 4% سنويًا، مدفوعة باستمرار الاستثمار في الذكاء الاصطناعي والتقنيات الرقمية<sup>2</sup>
- نسبة التكلفة إلى الدخل: 22.0% (تحسن من 24.3% في نفس الفترة من العام الماضي)<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>
- مخصصات انخفاض القيمة (صافي): 2.33 مليار درهم، بانخفاض 18% سنويًا<sup>2</sup>
- العائد على حقوق الملكية الملموسة (RoTE): 20.0% (أعلى من التوجيهات السنوية البالغة >16%)<sup>3</sup>
- نسبة الشق الأول من رأس المال (CET1): 13.7%<sup>3</sup>
- نسبة تغطية السيولة (LCR): 158%<sup>2</sup>

**المؤشرات التشغيلية:**
- نمو القروض والسلفيات والتمويل الإسلامي (صافي): 13% منذ بداية العام ليصل إلى 596 مليار درهم<sup>2</sup>
- نمو ودائع العملاء: 8% منذ بداية العام لتصل إلى 848 مليار درهم<sup>2</sup>
- نمو إجمالي الأصول: 14% منذ بداية العام لتصل إلى 1.38 تريليون درهم<sup>2</sup>
- نسبة تكلفة المخاطر: 55 نقطة أساس (أقل من التوجيه السنوي البالغ <75 نقطة أساس)<sup>3</sup>
- نسبة تغطية المخصصات: 106% (أعلى من التوجيه السنوي >90%)<sup>3</sup>
- نمو القروض الدولية: 23% منذ بداية العام، ونمو ودائع العمليات الدولية: 18%<sup>2</sup>
- مساهمة العمليات الدولية: 17% من إجمالي الإيرادات<sup>2</sup>

**أبرز التوجهات:**
- جميع قطاعات الأعمال سجلت إيرادات قياسية<sup>2</sup>
- الزخم مستمر ونتوقع تحقيق التوجيهات المالية للعام 2025<sup>3</sup>
- استمرار الاستثمار في التحول الرقمي والذكاء الاصطناعي مع الحفاظ على الكفاءة التشغيلية<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>

المصادر:
<sup>1</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q3 2025 p. 5](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=5)  
<sup>2</sup> [Euroland Company Fact sheet - Investor Relations page](https://www.bankfab.com/en-ae/about-fab/investor-relations)  
<sup>3</sup> [Q3 2025 Earnings Presentation p. 6, 13](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3038#page=6)

question: تطوير استراتيجية التوسع الدولي للبنك استناداً إلى أحدث تقرير.
answer:
استراتيجية التوسع الدولي لبنك أبوظبي الأول (FAB) تستند إلى عدة محاور رئيسية وفق أحدث التقارير، وتشمل:

- تعزيز النمو في الأسواق الدولية مع تحقيق نمو مزدوج الرقم في القروض والودائع ضمن الامتياز الدولي للبنك خلال 2025.
- التواجد في أكثر من 20 سوقًا عالميًا، مما يعزز مكانة FAB كمحور إقليمي للسيولة والتجارة وتدفقات الاستثمار عبر الحدود.
- مواصلة التوسع الاستراتيجي في أوروبا وتركيا ونيجيريا، بالإضافة إلى افتتاح فرع جديد في GIFT City بالهند (رهناً بالموافقات التنظيمية).
- تنويع مصادر الدخل من خلال تقديم حلول متخصصة للقطاعات، وزيادة البيع المتقاطع، وتعميق اختراق المنتجات لدى العملاء الدوليين.
- الاستفادة من شبكة البنك الدولية لتعزيز تدفقات التجارة والاستثمار، خاصة في الأسواق ذات الأولوية مثل المملكة المتحدة وفرنسا وسويسرا والسعودية.
- التركيز على تطوير القدرات الرقمية واعتماد الذكاء الاصطناعي لتحسين الكفاءة التشغيلية وتجربة العملاء في الأسواق الدولية.
- تعزيز مكانة البنك كمحور إقليمي للسيولة والتجارة والاستثمار عبر ربط الأسواق العالمية، مع التركيز على الممرات التجارية بين الشرق والغرب.

هذه الاستراتيجية تهدف إلى ترسيخ مكانة FAB كبنك عالمي رائد من الإمارات، معززة بنمو متنوع ومستدام عبر الأسواق الدولية ذات الأولوية<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.

question: تحليل اتجاه نمو الإيرادات مقارنة بنمو التكاليف خلال الفترات التقريبية الأخيرة للتقارير.
answer:
اتجاه نمو الإيرادات في بنك أبوظبي الأول خلال الفترات الأخيرة يُظهر تسارعاً واضحاً يفوق نمو التكاليف التشغيلية، ما أدى إلى تحسن الكفاءة التشغيلية بشكل ملحوظ:

- ارتفعت الإيرادات (الدخل التشغيلي) خلال التسعة أشهر الأولى من 2025 بنسبة 16% على أساس سنوي لتصل إلى 27.65 مليار درهم<sup>1</sup>.
- في المقابل، ارتفعت المصروفات التشغيلية بنسبة 4% فقط على أساس سنوي لتبلغ 6.07 مليار درهم لنفس الفترة<sup>2</sup>.
- نتيجة هذا الفارق في النمو، تحسّن معدل الكفاءة التشغيلية (نسبة التكاليف إلى الدخل) ليصل إلى 22.0%، وهو مستوى منخفض يعكس السيطرة على التكاليف مقارنة بنمو الإيرادات<sup>2</sup>.
- النمو في الإيرادات جاء مدعوماً بارتفاع الدخل من غير الفوائد بنسبة 37%، بينما ارتفع صافي دخل الفوائد بنسبة 2% فقط<sup>2</sup>.

الخلاصة: الإيرادات تنمو بوتيرة أسرع بكثير من التكاليف التشغيلية، ما يعزز ربحية البنك وكفاءته التشغيلية خلال الفترات الأخيرة.

المراجع:

<sup>1</sup> [Q3 2025 Press Release p. 1](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3044#page=1)  
<sup>2</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis p. 2-6](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=2)

question: تطور سياسة توزيع الأرباح للشركة بناءً على أحدث الأداء المالي والتوقعات المستقبلية.
answer:
شهدت سياسة توزيع الأرباح في بنك أبوظبي الأول تطوراً ملحوظاً في السنوات الأخيرة، مع الحفاظ على نهج منضبط ومتسق يوازن بين تحقيق عوائد مجزية للمساهمين ودعم النمو العضوي للبنك. فيما يلي أبرز التطورات والسياسة الحالية بناءً على أحدث النتائج المالية والتوقعات المستقبلية:

- في عام 2024، أوصى مجلس الإدارة ووافق المساهمون على توزيع أرباح نقدية بقيمة 8.3 مليار درهم، ما يعادل 75% من رأس المال المدفوع للبنك، أو 51% من صافي الأرباح القابلة للتوزيع، وتم دفعها للمساهمين المسجلين حتى 21 مارس 2025<sup>1</sup>.
- سياسة البنك ليست قائمة على نسبة توزيع ثابتة رسمية، بل تعتمد على تقييم سنوي يأخذ في الاعتبار الأداء المالي، متطلبات رأس المال، وتوجيهات المصرف المركزي الإماراتي الذي يضع سقفاً بنسبة 50% من صافي الأرباح القابلة للتوزيع<sup>2</sup>.
- خلال السنوات الثلاث الأخيرة، حافظ البنك على مستوى توزيعات أرباح متسق نسبياً، مع الالتزام بالحد الأقصى المسموح به من قبل المصرف المركزي، مع مراعاة وجود هامش احتياطي لرأس المال (CET1) فوق 13.5% قبل التوزيعات<sup>2</sup>.
- الأداء المالي للبنك في التسعة أشهر الأولى من 2025 كان قوياً جداً، حيث ارتفع صافي الربح بنسبة 24% على أساس سنوي ليصل إلى 16.02 مليار درهم، مع عائد على حقوق الملكية الملموسة (RoTE) بلغ 20%، ونسبة كفاية رأس المال الأساسي (CET1) عند 13.7% قبل التوزيعات، ما يعزز قدرة البنك على الاستمرار في توزيع أرباح مجزية مستقبلاً مع الحفاظ على متانة رأس المال<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.
- الإدارة أكدت في آخر الاتصالات مع المستثمرين أن قرار التوزيعات النهائية للعام 2025 سيُعلن عنه كالمعتاد في الربع الرابع من العام، مع استمرار النهج المنضبط الذي يوازن بين العائد للمساهمين ودعم النمو، مع الأخذ في الاعتبار سقف التوزيع المركزي ومتطلبات رأس المال<sup>2</sup>.

التوقعات المستقبلية:
- مع استمرار قوة الأداء المالي وتحقيق نمو مزدوج الرقم في القروض وصافي الأرباح، من المتوقع أن يحافظ البنك على سياسة توزيعات سخية ومنضبطة، مع الالتزام بتعليمات المصرف المركزي، ومراعاة متطلبات رأس المال والنمو المستقبلي<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.

<sup>2</sup> [Q3 2024 Earnings Call Transcript p. 10](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/326#page=10)  
<sup>3</sup> [Q3 2025 Earnings Presentation p. 6](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3038#page=6)  
<sup>4</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q3 2025 p. 7](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=7)

question: How has FAB’s performance evolved over the past few years?
answer:
FAB’s performance over the past few years has shown strong, consistent growth across all key financial and operational metrics:

**2025 (Year-to-date, as of Q3):**
- Net profit for the first nine months reached AED 16.02 billion, up 24% year-on-year, with Q3 net profit at AED 5.39 billion (+21% yoy)<sup>1</sup>.
- Operating income for 9M’25 rose 16% yoy to AED 27.65 billion<sup>1</sup>.
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) at 20.0%, well above the >16% guidance<sup>1</sup>.
- Total assets grew to AED 1.38 trillion, up 14% year-to-date<sup>1</sup>.
- Loans and advances grew 13% ytd to AED 596 billion; customer deposits increased 8% ytd to AED 848 billion<sup>1</sup>.
- Non-interest income surged 37% yoy to AED 12.70 billion, now 46% of Group revenue<sup>1</sup>.
- Cost-to-income ratio improved to 22.0%<sup>1</sup>.
- Capital and liquidity remain robust, with a CET1 ratio of 13.7% and LCR of 158%<sup>1</sup>.

**2024:**
- For the first nine months, net profit was AED 12.9 billion (+4% yoy), and operating income reached AED 23.9 billion (+16% yoy)<sup>2</sup>.
- Total assets at AED 1.2 trillion (+5% ytd)<sup>2</sup>.
- Cost-to-income ratio improved from 25.4% to 24.3%<sup>2</sup>.
- International revenue grew 33% yoy, highlighting the expanding global footprint<sup>2</sup>.

**2023 and Earlier:**
- In 2022, net profit was AED 7.5 billion for the first nine months (excluding a one-off gain), down from AED 8.9 billion in 2021 due to lower investment gains, but supported by improved net interest margins<sup>3</sup>.
- FAB has consistently delivered profit growth since the merger of FGB and NBAD in 2017, with net profit rising from AED 10.9 billion in 2017 to AED 12.0 billion in 2018 (+10% yoy)<sup>4</sup>.

**Strategic and Operational Highlights:**
- FAB has maintained a strong AA- credit rating and robust capital base throughout this period<sup>1</sup>.
- The bank continues to invest in digital transformation and AI, driving efficiency and customer engagement<sup>1</sup>.
- Sustainable and transition financing facilitated to date rose to AED 284 billion, or 57% of the Group’s 2030 target of AED 500 billion<sup>1</sup>.
- The international business now contributes 17% of Group revenue, with international loans and deposits up 23% and 18% ytd, respectively<sup>1</sup>.

**Summary Table (Key Metrics):**

| Year/Period     | Net Profit (AED bn) | Operating Income (AED bn) | RoTE (%) | Total Assets (AED tn) | Cost/Income (%) |
|-----------------|---------------------|---------------------------|----------|----------------------|-----------------|
| 9M 2025         | 16.02 (+24% yoy)    | 27.65 (+16% yoy)          | 20.0     | 1.38 (+14% ytd)      | 22.0            |
| 9M 2024         | 12.9 (+4% yoy)      | 23.9 (+16% yoy)           | —        | 1.2 (+5% ytd)        | 24.3            |
| 9M 2022         | 7.5 (-15% yoy)*     | —                         | —        | —                    | —               |
| FY 2018         | 12.0 (+10% yoy)     | —                         | —        | —                    | —               |
| FY 2017         | 10.9                | —                         | —        | —                    | —               |

*Excluding one-off gain on Magnati sale.

References:
<sup>1</sup> [Euroland Company Fact sheet](https://www.bankfab.com/en-ae/about-fab/investor-relations)
<sup>2</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q3 2024 p. 2](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1215#page=2)
<sup>3</sup> [Moody's Report p. 13](https://www.bankfab.com/-/media/fab-uds/about-fab/investor-relations/debt-investor-information/credit-ratings/pdfs/moodysreport.pdf#page=13)
<sup>4</sup> [FAB Analyst & Investor Day 2019 p. 10](https://www.bankfab.com/-/media/fab-uds/about-fab/investor-relations/reports-and-presentations/presentations/pdfs/fab-analyst-and-investor-day-2019-presentation.pdf#page=10)

question: How is FAB progressing on sustainability and ESG?
answer:
FAB is making significant progress on sustainability and ESG, with a clear strategy, robust governance, and strong execution across environmental, social, and governance pillars:

**Strategic Commitments and Targets**
- Our ESG strategy is built on three pillars: transitioning to a low-carbon future, transforming our governance model, and capitalizing on social responsibility<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.
- We have committed to become net zero in our own operations (Scope 1 & 2) by 2030, and on financed emissions by 2050. For Scope 3, we have set targets for the oil & gas, power generation, and aviation sectors, covering 80% of our financed emissions<sup>2</sup>.
- Our sustainable finance commitment has increased to USD 135 billion by 2030, aimed at lending, investing, and facilitating business in environmental and socially responsible solutions<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.

**Governance and Integration**
- ESG principles are fully integrated into our governance framework, with oversight from the Board Risk and ESG Committee (BRESGC), Group ESG Committee (G-ESGC), and ESG & Sustainable Finance Committee (ESG-SFC)<sup>5</sup><sup>6</sup>.
- In 2024, we enhanced our ESG governance structure, developed a standalone Climate Risk Framework and Policy, and embedded ESG risk metrics into our Risk Appetite Framework<sup>7</sup><sup>8</sup>.
- ESG-related KPIs are now part of the performance evaluation and incentives for the Board and senior leadership<sup>6</sup>.

**Execution and Reporting**
- In 2024, we delivered 27,184 hours of ESG training to employees (about 4 hours per employee), and 99% of staff received anti-corruption training<sup>9</sup>.
- All sustainable finance transactions are reviewed for ESG risks and tracked through our Sustainable Finance Framework, with annual reporting on progress in our ESG and Sustainable Finance Reports<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.
- We publish a wide range of ESG disclosures, including ESG Reports, Principles for Responsible Banking Reports, Sustainable Finance Reports, Equator Principles Reports, and our Pathway to Net Zero Report<sup>10</sup>.

**Recognition and Alignment**
- FAB is a signatory to the Net Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), the Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials (PCAF), and aligns with leading frameworks such as GRI, PRB, Equator Principles, and TCFD<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>11</sup>.
- We support national and global sustainability goals, including the UAE Net Zero by 2050, UN SDGs, and the UAE Private Sector Pledge to Accelerate Gender Balance<sup>1</sup>.

**Impact and Case Studies**
- Our sustainable finance initiatives include landmark deals such as a USD 1.2 billion Sustainable Linked Loan for Etihad Airways and the region’s first green bond, which financed 13 green projects across multiple countries<sup>3</sup>.
- ESG risk metrics are actively monitored, and we regularly review the transition maturity of our highest emitting clients, covering 95% of financed emissions in priority sectors<sup>6</sup>.

**External Ratings**
- As of September 2025, our ESG ratings are: Sustainalytics 16.9, MSCI AA, and Refinitiv 79<sup>12</sup>.

References:

<sup>2</sup> [Second Party Opinion by ISS on FAB Sustainable Finance p. 67](https://www.bankfab.com/-/media/fab-uds/about-fab/sustainability/reports-policy-frameworks/documents/spo-fab-011223.pdf#page=67)

<sup>6</sup> [ESG report 2024 p. 45](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1739#page=45)

answer:
اتجاه نمو الإيرادات والتكاليف في بنك أبوظبي الأول خلال الفترات الأخيرة يُظهر ما يلي:

- ارتفعت إيرادات المجموعة (الدخل التشغيلي) خلال التسعة أشهر الأولى من 2025 بنسبة 16% على أساس سنوي لتصل إلى 27.65 مليار درهم، مدفوعة بزخم مستدام وتنوع مصادر الدخل وهامش ربحية مرن.
- في المقابل، ارتفعت المصروفات التشغيلية بنسبة 4% فقط على أساس سنوي لتصل إلى 6.07 مليار درهم، نتيجة استمرار الاستثمار في الذكاء الاصطناعي والتحول الرقمي والتقنيات الحديثة.
- تحسن معدل التكلفة إلى الدخل ليصل إلى 22.0%، ما يعكس كفاءة عالية في إدارة التكاليف مقارنة بنمو الإيرادات.
- صافي الربح ارتفع بنسبة 24% ليصل إلى 16.02 مليار درهم خلال نفس الفترة، مما يدل على أن نمو الإيرادات كان أعلى بكثير من نمو التكاليف<sup>1</sup>.

الخلاصة: وتيرة نمو الإيرادات في بنك أبوظبي الأول خلال الفترات الأخيرة كانت أعلى بكثير من وتيرة نمو التكاليف، ما أدى إلى تحسن واضح في الكفاءة التشغيلية وزيادة الربحية.

question: Which regulations do you comply with
answer:
We comply with a wide range of regulations and standards across all jurisdictions where we operate, including:

- UAE federal laws and regulations, especially those issued by the Central Bank of the UAE (CBUAE)
- Authorisation and licensing by the Securities and Commodities Authority (SCA) as a Securities Services Provider
- International standards such as the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) recommendations and global best practices
- Anti-Money Laundering (AML), Counter Terrorist Financing (CTF), Sanctions, Proliferation Financing (PF), and Anti-Bribery and Corruption (AB&C) laws and regulations in all relevant jurisdictions
- Sanctions administered or enforced by the Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC, U.S. Department of Treasury), United Nations Security Council (UNSC), the European Union, and His Majesty's Treasury of the United Kingdom, as well as local sanctions and anti-corruption laws
- UAE’s Federal Law No (4) of 2012 on the Regulation of Competition (anti-competition/anti-monopoly)
- Consumer Protection Regulation (CPR) and Federal Law on the Protection of Personal Data, as well as international data privacy frameworks like Singapore’s Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA)
- Basel III capital adequacy and disclosure requirements
- Shari’ah compliance for Islamic banking activities, overseen by the Internal Shari’ah Supervision Committee (ISSC)
- Labour laws, ESG standards, and human rights protocols, including the UN TIP Protocol and UN Resolution 55/15 on human trafficking
- UAE Corporate Income Tax (CIT) and related tax transparency and reporting obligations

Our compliance framework is regularly reviewed and updated to reflect new and amended regulatory requirements, and we maintain robust internal controls, governance, and independent audit functions to ensure ongoing adherence<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup><sup>5</sup><sup>6</sup><sup>7</sup><sup>8</sup>.

question: What is your approach to risk management
answer:
Our approach to risk management is comprehensive and embedded across all levels of the organization, ensuring we deliver risk-adjusted returns while safeguarding our stakeholders and maintaining regulatory compliance. Here’s how we manage risk at FAB:

- **Risk Governance & Structure**
  - The Board of Directors sets the risk management tone and is responsible for the overall direction, supervision, and control of risk. Oversight is delegated to specialist committees, notably the Board Risk & ESG Committee (BRESGC), which oversees risk strategy, frameworks, appetite, and culture<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.
  - We operate a robust "three lines of defence" model:
    - **First line:** Business units and support functions identify, own, and manage risks in their daily operations, ensuring activities are within our risk appetite.
    - **Second line:** Independent risk management and compliance functions provide oversight, develop policies, monitor exposures, and challenge the first line.
    - **Third line:** Internal Audit provides independent assurance to the Board and senior management on the effectiveness of risk management, control, and governance processes<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.

- **Risk Management Framework**
  - Our framework covers all material risks, including credit, market, liquidity, operational, capital, legal, compliance, ESG, model, and shari’ah compliance risks.
  - We establish a formal risk appetite, reviewed regularly by executive management and the Board, reflecting our business strategy and market environment.
  - Risk monitoring and control are based on defined limits, scenario analysis, credit risk mitigation (collateral, guarantees, netting), and risk transfer mechanisms such as hedging for interest and currency risks.
  - All major transactions are assessed and authorized by appropriate management before execution, with ongoing monitoring of risk mitigation effectiveness<sup>1</sup><sup>5</sup>.

- **Operational Risk Management**
  - We implement an operational risk management cycle aligned with Basel standards, covering identification, assessment, mitigation, control, and monitoring.
  - Operational risks are identified by business owners using risk matrices, covering all products, services, processes, and channels, including outsourced activities.
  - The Group Operational & Fraud Risk Committee (GOFRC) provides oversight on operational and fraud risks, ensuring alignment with business strategies and risk priorities<sup>4</sup>.

- **Risk Measurement & Reporting**
  - We use advanced risk measurement systems, including Value at Risk (VaR) models for market risk, and regularly perform stress testing and scenario analyses.
  - Risk reports are tailored and submitted periodically to the Board, risk committees, and senior management, ensuring informed decision-making and sound risk management<sup>3</sup>.

- **Integration & Culture**
  - Our risk appetite is embedded into decision-making and business strategy, fostering a strong risk culture and operational discipline at all levels.
  - Regular training and awareness initiatives are conducted for staff and customers to maintain a robust risk culture<sup>1</sup>.

- **Compliance & Best Practices**
  - The risk management framework and strategies are dynamically updated in line with regulatory requirements and market best practices.
  - We comply with the Basel Standardised approach for risk-weighted assets and capital requirements, and maintain optimal capital adequacy as per our risk appetite<sup>3</sup>.

References:

question: What Geographies do you address
answer:
We address two primary geographic segments: the UAE and International markets. Our business is managed through a network of branches, subsidiaries, and representative offices across these regions. The UAE remains our core market, accounting for 83% of total operating income, while our international operations contribute 17% and reflect our growing global footprint across 20+ markets<sup>1</sup>.

question: What is Fab's carbon footprint
answer:
FAB’s carbon footprint is managed and disclosed through a comprehensive approach covering both operational and financed emissions:

- We have set 2019 as our baseline year for greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions reporting, with a third-party materiality assessment conducted to determine our baseline emissions. The UAE and Egypt offices account for over 97% of our total emissions. Our Group GHG inventory is regularly expanded and enhanced for optimal disclosure, and we are working to include more Scope 3 categories, such as employee commuting<sup>1</sup>.
- FAB is committed to achieving net zero emissions by 2050, both in our own operations and across our financed portfolio. We have applied emission reduction net zero targets to 8 high-emitting sectors within our loan portfolio, which represent approximately 90% of financed emissions. We have also ceased new financing for coal-fired mining and coal-based power generation<sup>2</sup>.
- Since January 2022, we calculate financed emissions in line with the PCAF (Partnership for Carbon Accounting Financials) methodology and disclose GHG emissions of our financial portfolio accordingly. Our targets focus on reducing carbon-related financed emissions in Oil & Gas, Power Generation, and Aviation, which together account for 80% of our total financed emissions<sup>3</sup>.
- FAB’s sustainability and net zero reports, including detailed methodologies and progress against our targets, are available on our website<sup>4</sup>.

question: How is FAB leveraging AI and digital innovation to drive growth?
answer:
We are leveraging AI and digital innovation as core drivers of growth and transformation across the bank. Here’s how:

- **AI Integration Across Operations:** We have embedded AI in our daily operations, with solutions like the Agentic AI platform, Microsoft 365 Copilot for all employees, and AI-powered onboarding and credit analytics. Innovations such as the Board AI Observer, Voice Concierge, and planning tools are already delivering measurable improvements in efficiency and service quality<sup>1</sup>.
- **Scaling AI Agents:** We have deployed 18 live AI agents across Trade Operations, Customer Service, and Finance Analytics, doubling processing capacity and reducing turnaround times by up to 50%. All employees are now AI-enabled, fundamentally redefining how we work<sup>2</sup>.
- **AI Innovation Hub:** In partnership with Microsoft, we launched an AI Innovation Hub focused on developing new AI-based banking capabilities, accelerating adoption of generative AI, intelligent automation, and machine learning. The Hub drives product enhancement, personalization, unique AI risk models, and new digital solutions<sup>3</sup>.
- **Strategic Partnerships:** We have formed key partnerships with global AI leaders including Microsoft, G42, and Presight, and are migrating our data center and workloads to Microsoft Azure to access advanced cloud and AI solutions<sup>3</sup>.
- **Customer-Centric Digital Transformation:** 96% of all transactions are now conducted digitally, and we’ve seen a 46% increase in digital transactions. GenAI-powered tools like Voice Concierge, intelligent email routing, and real-time fraud detection are redefining customer service with seamless, zero-touch experiences<sup>4</sup><sup>1</sup>.
- **API and Emerging Tech Integration:** Our API infrastructure now supports integration with AI, machine learning, and blockchain, enabling innovative solutions and enhancing our service capabilities<sup>5</sup>.
- **Continuous Modernization:** We are executing a comprehensive five-year roadmap to modernize infrastructure and applications, expand digital infrastructure, and increase cloud adoption, ensuring we remain agile and future-ready<sup>6</sup>.
- **Recognition for Innovation:** Our digital efforts have been recognized with awards such as 'Best User Experience Design' (FAB Mobile), 'Best in Transformation,' and 'Best in Innovation' (FAB Chat) at the Global Finance Awards 2024<sup>4</sup>.

question: What is the financial outlook for FAB?
answer:
Our financial outlook remains strong and positive, supported by robust performance across all business segments and a favorable macroeconomic environment in the UAE.

**Key highlights of our financial outlook and guidance:**

- We delivered a record net profit of AED 16.02 billion for the first nine months of 2025 (9M'25), up 24% year-on-year, driven by strong execution and diversified revenue streams.
- Operating income for 9M'25 rose 16% year-on-year to AED 27.65 billion, with resilient margins and sustained momentum.
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) reached 20.0% for 9M'25, performing ahead of our >16% guidance.
- Total assets grew to AED 1.38 trillion, up 14% year-to-date, reflecting consistent growth in both loans and deposits.
- Loan growth guidance for FY'25 is "low double-digit," with 13% year-to-date growth already achieved.
- Net impairment charges for 9M'25 were AED 2.33 billion, down 18% year-on-year, resulting in a cost of risk of 55 bps—well below our full-year guidance of <75 bps.
- Our capital and liquidity positions remain strong, with a CET1 ratio of 13.7% and a Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) of 158%.
- The macro outlook for the UAE is positive, with real GDP growth forecast at approximately 5.2% for FY'25 and 5.6% for FY'26.
- We anticipate 2 additional interest rate cuts in Q4'25 and 2-3 more in FY'26.
- All business divisions are delivering record revenue, and our international franchise continues to grow, contributing 17% of Group revenue for 9M'25.
- We are well on track to meet our FY'25 financial guidance and enter the final quarter of 2025 with solid momentum<sup>1</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Euroland Company Fact sheet](https://www.bankfab.com/en-ae/about-fab/investor-relations)

question: what differentiates FAB from other local banks?
answer:
What sets FAB apart from other local banks:

- **Largest Bank in the UAE:** FAB is the largest bank in the UAE by total assets, with AED 1.38 trillion (USD 376 billion) as of September 2025<sup>1</sup>.
- **Global Footprint:** We operate across more than 20 markets, providing a true gateway between the Middle East, North Africa, and the world<sup>1</sup>.
- **Strong Credit Ratings:** FAB holds the highest combined credit ratings among MENA banks (Aa3/AA-/AA- from Moody’s, S&P, and Fitch) with a stable outlook<sup>1</sup>.
- **Diversified Business Model:** Our structure spans three major business units—Investment Banking & Markets, Wholesale Banking, and Personal, Business, Wealth & Privileged Client Banking—serving both wholesale and retail clients<sup>1</sup>.
- **Sustainability Leadership:** FAB is a regional leader in sustainable finance, holding an MSCI ESG rating of ‘AA’, ranked among the top 6% of banks globally by Refinitiv ESG Scores, and recognized as the Best diversified bank in MENA by Sustainalytics ESG Risk Rating<sup>1</sup>.
- **Digital and Innovation Leadership:** We are recognized for best-in-class digital transformation and AI implementation, including awards for Best AI Technology Implementation and The UAE’s Best Digital Bank for Large Corporates<sup>1</sup>.
- **Unique International Capabilities:** FAB is the only UAE bank with a fully licensed branch in Mainland China and is the first MENA bank to join CIPS as a Direct Participant, enhancing cross-border RMB payment solutions and regional cash management capabilities<sup>2</sup>.
- **Financial Performance:** We delivered a record net profit of AED 16.02 billion for the first nine months of 2025, up 24% year-on-year, and a Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) of 20.0%<sup>3</sup>.
- **Government Linkages and Support:** FAB’s flagship status and close ties to the Abu Dhabi government provide a strong foundation for stability, funding, and growth<sup>4</sup>.

question: What is the outlook for your non-funded income line? Can we expect it to be 60% repeatable as communicated previously?
answer:
Our outlook for non-funded income remains robust and is a key pillar of our revenue diversification strategy. Here’s what you need to know:

- Non-funded income contributed 46% of total Group revenue for the first nine months of 2025, up from 38% in the prior year period. This reflects our ongoing strategic focus on scaling up fee and trading businesses across all divisions<sup>1</sup>.
- Non-interest income surged 37% year-on-year to AED 12.70 billion for 9M’25, with strong growth across all components—fees and commissions, FX, and investment income<sup>2</sup>.
- Management continues to estimate that around 60% of our non-funded income is “sticky and repeatable.” This view has been reiterated consistently over recent quarters, and we remain confident in this level of repeatability going forward<sup>3</sup>.
- The recurring nature of this income is supported by consistent fee generation, robust client flows, and the structural relevance of our global markets and wealth management businesses<sup>3</sup>.
- While there can be some quarter-to-quarter volatility—especially in trading and “other income” lines—our underlying franchise strength and cross-sell capabilities support a high degree of income stability<sup>3</sup>.

question: Your NPLs declined in Q3 to 2.6%, what drove this? What is your outlook on this metric?
answer:
Our non-performing loans (NPL) ratio declined to 2.6% as of Q3 2025, down from 3.8% a year earlier—a significant improvement of 122 basis points. This drop was primarily driven by subdued NPL formation and an accelerated pace of write-offs, supported by a strong macro-economic backdrop. Impairment charges for the first nine months of 2025 fell 18% year-on-year to AED 2.33bn, reflecting both lower new NPL inflows and active portfolio management. Provision coverage also strengthened to 106%, up from 95% in the prior year, further enhancing our balance sheet resilience<sup>1</sup>.

Looking ahead, our outlook on asset quality remains positive. The macro environment in the UAE continues to be supportive, and we are maintaining disciplined risk management. While we do not provide explicit forward guidance on the NPL ratio, the current trend of low NPL formation and strong coverage levels positions us well to sustain robust asset quality metrics through the remainder of the year<sup>1</sup>.

question: What are the main drivers behind FAB’s growth strategy?
answer:
The main drivers behind FAB’s growth strategy are:

- **Diversified Revenue Streams & Client-Centric Solutions:** Our growth is propelled by broad-based revenue generation across all business segments, with a strong focus on client-centric solutions. In the first nine months of 2025, we delivered a record net profit of AED 16.02 billion (up 24% yoy), driven by robust performance in Investment Banking & Markets (revenue up 17% yoy), Wholesale Banking (revenue up 12% yoy), and Personal, Business, Wealth & Privileged Client Banking (revenue up 12% yoy). Our international franchise contributed 17% of Group revenue, with loans and deposits rising 23% and 18% year-to-date, respectively<sup>1</sup>.

- **Geographic Expansion & Global Connectivity:** We continue to expand our footprint across more than 20 global markets, reinforcing our role as a regional anchor for cross-border capital, trade, and investment flows. Recent growth corridors include Asia, MENA, Europe, and the UK. New representative offices in Nigeria and Turkey, and a branch in GIFT City, India, further strengthen our international presence<sup>1</sup>.

- **Digital Transformation & AI Adoption:** Accelerating digital innovation is core to our strategy. We are scaling AI-driven solutions across operations, with 18 live AI agents deployed in areas such as Trade Operations and Customer Service, reducing turnaround times by up to 50%. Over 96% of service requests are now processed digitally, and we have launched an AI Innovation Hub in partnership with Microsoft to further embed advanced AI capabilities across the Group<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.

- **Sustainability Leadership:** FAB is committed to leading in sustainable finance, having facilitated AED 327 billion in sustainable and transition financing to date—65% of our AED 500 billion 2030 target. This aligns with our strategy to embed ESG principles across our business and governance frameworks<sup>1</sup>.

- **Product & Service Innovation:** We continue to introduce innovative products and exemplary customer service, particularly in Private Banking and Wealth Management. Our international booking centres now account for 40% of consolidated Private Banking revenues, with significant growth in the UK, France, Switzerland, and Saudi Arabia<sup>3</sup>.

- **Strategic Partnerships & Industry Collaboration:** We leverage strategic partnerships in areas such as supply chain finance, cross-border payments, and fintech ecosystems. Our collaboration with Microsoft and other global AI leaders accelerates our digital transformation and positions us as a market innovator<sup>2</sup>.

- **Operational Excellence & Risk Management:** We maintain strong capital and liquidity positions (CET1 ratio of 13.7%, LCR of 158%), disciplined cost management (cost-to-income ratio at 22.0%), and a high-quality risk profile, supporting sustainable growth and resilience<sup>1</sup>.

References:  
<sup>1</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q3 2025 p. 4](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=4)

question: How has FAB’s performance evolved over the past few years?
answer:
FAB’s performance over the past few years has shown strong and consistent growth, marked by record profitability, expanding business volumes, and robust returns:

**2025 (Year-to-date through Q3):**
- Net profit for the first nine months reached AED 16.02 billion, up 24% year-on-year.
- Group revenue (operating income) rose 16% to AED 27.65 billion.
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) stood at 20.0%, well above the medium-term target of >16%.
- Total assets grew to AED 1.38 trillion, up 14% year-to-date.
- Non-interest income surged 37% year-on-year, now contributing 46% of Group revenue.
- Cost-to-income ratio improved to 22.0%, and net impairment charges dropped 18% year-on-year.
- All business divisions delivered record revenue, with international operations contributing 17% of Group revenue and international loans and deposits up 23% and 18% year-to-date, respectively<sup>1</sup>.

**2024 (Full Year):**
- Net profit after tax rose 4% to AED 17.1 billion, despite absorbing the impact of the newly introduced UAE corporate tax.
- Profit before tax reached AED 19.9 billion, up 13% year-on-year.
- Operating income grew 15% to AED 31.6 billion, driven by strong business volumes and improved margins.
- Net interest income reached AED 19.6 billion, up 8% year-on-year, with net interest margin (NIM) improving to 1.93%.
- RoTE for 2024 was 16.8%, in line with guidance<sup>2</sup>.

**2023 and Earlier:**
- 2023 and 2024 were both characterized by double-digit revenue and profit growth, supported by operational efficiencies, a strong balance sheet, and a diversified business model.
- The bank’s total asset base crossed the AED 1.2 trillion threshold in 2024, reflecting ongoing expansion and business momentum<sup>3</sup>.

**Strategic and Operational Highlights:**
- FAB has maintained the region’s strongest credit ratings (AA- or equivalent) and a robust capital and liquidity position.
- The bank continues to invest in AI, digital transformation, and sustainability, including the issuance of the UAE’s first-ever Social Bonds and the region’s first blockchain-based digital bond.
- International expansion has accelerated, with new branches and increased presence in Europe, Turkey, Nigeria, and India.
- FAB’s business mix is increasingly diversified, with non-funds income and international operations contributing more significantly to overall results<sup>1</sup>.

**Summary:**  
Over the past few years, FAB has delivered record financial results, sustained double-digit growth in profits and revenues, and strengthened its position as the UAE’s global bank. The Group remains on track to meet or exceed its financial guidance, driven by disciplined execution, innovation, and a focus on sustainable, diversified growth.

References:  
<sup>1</sup> [Euroland Company Fact sheet](https://www.bankfab.com/en-ae/about-fab/investor-relations)  
<sup>2</sup> [Annual Report 2024 p. 14](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/436#page=14)  
<sup>3</sup> [1st Quarter Analyses Report 2024 p. 3](https://www.bankfab.com/-/media/fab-uds/about-fab/investor-relations/reports-and-presentations/quarterly-and-annual-reports/2024/fab-mda-q1-2024-english.pdf#page=3)

question: What is the outlook for net interest margins?
answer:
Our outlook for net interest margins (NIM) reflects the recent trend of resilience but also recognizes some pressure from lower benchmark rates and shifts in deposit mix:

- Group NIM for Q3'25 was 1.76%, down 4bps quarter-on-quarter and 13bps from the Q1'25 peak of 1.97%. The decline primarily reflects a shift in deposit mix and the impact of lower benchmark rates, including a 25bps Fed rate cut in September 2025<sup>1</sup>.
- For the first nine months of 2025, Group NIM averaged 1.84%, which is 9bps lower year-on-year, mainly due to the lower rate environment<sup>1</sup>.
- Management estimates that a -25bps parallel movement in interest rates would have a P&L impact of approximately AED 200 million if no offsetting action is taken<sup>1</sup>.
- The Q2'25 NIM was 1.80%, 17bps lower quarter-on-quarter, reflecting lower IIS recoveries and higher central bank placements<sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- The overall message is that while margins remain resilient, we expect some continued pressure in the near term as rate cuts filter through and deposit mix evolves. However, our disciplined pricing and strong business momentum help to mitigate some of this impact<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.

References:  
<sup>1</sup> [Q3 2025 Earnings Presentation p. 11](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3038#page=11)

<sup>3</sup> [Investor Presentation Q2 2025 p. 25](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/2711#page=25)

question: How is FAB progressing on sustainability and ESG?
answer:
We are making strong, measurable progress on sustainability and ESG, with a comprehensive strategy and clear targets:

**Strategic Commitments and Achievements**
- We have committed to lend, invest, and facilitate AED 500 billion (USD 136 billion) in sustainable and transition financing by 2030. By the end of 2024, we had achieved 53% of this target<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- Our sustainable finance target was increased by 80% in 2023, making it the largest such commitment by any MENA bank to date<sup>4</sup>.
- We are fully aligned with the UAE’s Net Zero by 2050 Strategic Initiative and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)<sup>5</sup>.

**ESG Integration and Governance**
- ESG principles are embedded in our culture, operations, and risk management. In 2024, we introduced a Group Climate Risk Policy and Framework, and developed climate risk scoring and stress testing tools<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.
- Our governance structure includes a Board Risk and ESG Committee, Group ESG Committee, and an ESG & Sustainable Finance Committee, ensuring oversight and accountability across the Group<sup>6</sup>.

**Climate and Environmental Leadership**
- We are committed to net zero for our own operations (Scope 1 and 2) by 2030, and for financed emissions by 2050<sup>7</sup>.
- FAB is Chair of the Net-Zero Banking Alliance Steering Group and Co-Chair of PCAF’s MENA chapter. We were the first bank in MENA to publish a TNFD-aligned report<sup>3</sup>.
- We actively participate in global climate forums, such as COP28 and COP29, and support the UAE’s climate finance ambitions<sup>4</sup>.

**Social Responsibility and Inclusion**
- We supported SMEs with AED 4.3 billion in new financing in 2024, a 30% increase year-on-year<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.
- Emiratisation reached 47% of our 50% target, and female representation in senior leadership increased to 16% (from 9% in 2021)<sup>3</sup>.
- Over 9,200 volunteers participated in 60 community programmes in 2024<sup>3</sup>.

**Transparency and Reporting**
- We publish annual ESG, Sustainable Finance, and Equator Principles reports, prepared in line with GRI Standards and ADX ESG Disclosure Guidance<sup>8</sup>.
- All ESG deals are tracked and monitored monthly, with proceeds from green/social/transition bonds ring-fenced for eligible projects<sup>9</sup>.

**Recognition**
- FAB was included in TIME and Statista’s list of the World’s 500 Most Sustainable Companies<sup>3</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Annual Report 2024 p. 56](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/436#page=56)

question: what is the menagement
answer:
Our management structure is organized as follows:

**Board of Directors**
- The Board is the principal decision-making body, responsible for overall strategy, monitoring performance, and ensuring strong corporate governance. The Board currently has 11 non-executive members, including a Chairman and Vice Chairman. Board members are elected for three-year terms and must seek re-election for additional terms<sup>1</sup>.
- The Chairman leads the Board, while the Group Chief Executive Officer (GCEO) manages day-to-day operations, supported by the executive management team. The roles of Chairman and GCEO are separate and independent<sup>1</sup>.

**Senior Management Team**
- **Group Chief Executive Officer:** Hana Al Rostamani
- **Group Head of Personal, Business, Wealth & Privileged Client Banking Group:** Futoon Hamdan Al Mazrouei
- **Group Chief Financial Officer:** Lars Kramer
- **Group Head of Investment Banking & Markets:** Pantelis (Linos) D. Lekkas
- **Group Head of Wholesale Banking:** Martin Tricaud
- **Group Chief Risk Officer:** Chris Jaques
- **Group Chief Technology & Transformation Officer:** Divyesh Vithlani
- **Group Chief Operations Officer:** Keith Macdonald
- **Group Chief Human Resources Officer:** Noora Al Reyasi
- **Group Chief Compliance Officer:** Simon Thorn
- **Group Chief Audit Officer:** Nurendra Perera
- **Group Head of International Banking:** Omar Hafeez<sup>2</sup>

**Management Committees**
- The Group Executive Committee (EXCO) is the highest management-level committee, responsible for decisions on strategy, budgets, capital management, risk, and key policies. EXCO may delegate certain authorities to other management committees and individuals but retains authority over major matters<sup>3</sup>.
- Other management-level committees include the Group Credit Committee (GCC) and Group Risk Committee (GRC), among others<sup>3</sup>.

**Business Segments**
- Our operating structure consists of four main segments:
  - Investment Banking & Markets (IB&M)
  - Wholesale Banking (WB)
  - Personal, Business, Wealth & Privileged Client Banking Group (PBW&PCBG)
  - Head Office (HO), which includes support functions and results of certain subsidiaries<sup>4</sup>.

question: How has FAB’s performance evolved over the past few years?
answer:
FAB’s performance has shown strong and consistent growth over the past several years, marked by record profitability, diversified revenue streams, and robust balance sheet expansion. Here’s how our performance has evolved:

**2023–2025: Record Growth and Diversification**
- Net profit for the first nine months of 2025 reached AED 16.02 billion, up 24% year-on-year, with Q3 2025 net profit at AED 5.39 billion (+21% yoy).
- Operating income for 9M 2025 rose 16% year-on-year to AED 27.65 billion.
- Return on Tangible Equity (RoTE) for 9M 2025 was 20.0%, well above our medium-term guidance of >16%.
- Total assets grew to AED 1.38 trillion as of Q3 2025, up 14% year-to-date, driven by consistent growth in both loans and deposits.
- Non-interest income surged 37% yoy to AED 12.70 billion in 9M 2025, now contributing 46% of Group revenue, reflecting our success in building recurring and diversified income streams.
- All business divisions delivered record revenue, and our international franchise contributed 17% of Group revenue in 9M 2025, with international loans and deposits rising 23% and 18% ytd, respectively.
- Our cost-to-income ratio improved to 22.0%, and net impairment charges fell 18% yoy to AED 2.33 billion, reflecting strong risk management and efficiency gains.
- Capital and liquidity remain robust, with a CET1 ratio of 13.7% and a Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR) of 158%<sup>1</sup>.

**2024: Sustained Momentum and Resilience**
- Group profit before tax in 2024 was AED 19.9 billion (+13% yoy), and net profit after tax rose 4% to AED 17.1 billion, despite absorbing the impact of the UAE corporate tax.
- Operating income grew 15% yoy to AED 31.6 billion, driven by strong business volumes, improved margins, and continued diversified growth across businesses and geographies.
- Net interest income reached AED 19.6 billion (+8% yoy), with net interest margin (NIM) at 1.93%, up 13 bps from 2023<sup>2</sup>.

**2023 and Earlier: Foundation for Growth**
- FAB delivered double-digit net profit growth in 2018 (+10% yoy), with net profit rising from AED 10.9 billion in 2017 to AED 12.0 billion in 2018, despite integration efforts following the merger of FGB and NBAD.
- The bank has consistently focused on maximizing shareholder return, strengthening its leadership position in the UAE, and expanding internationally<sup>3</sup>.

**Strategic and Operational Highlights**
- FAB maintains the region’s strongest credit ratings (AA- or equivalent), a robust capital base, and ample liquidity.
- We have accelerated investments in technology and AI, driving both opportunity and efficiency.
- Our international business now represents a significant and growing share of Group revenue, supporting further diversification and resilience<sup>1</sup>.

**Shareholder Value**
- Dividend per share for 2024 was AED 0.75, with a dividend yield of 4.26%<sup>1</sup>.

**Summary Table: Key Metrics Evolution**

| Metric (AED bn)           | 2017  | 2018  | 2024   | 9M 2025 |
|---------------------------|-------|-------|--------|---------|
| Net Profit                | 10.9  | 12.0  | 17.1   | 16.02*  |
| Operating Income          | —     | —     | 31.6   | 27.65   |
| Total Assets (trillion)   | —     | —     | 1.2+   | 1.38    |
| RoTE (%)                  | —     | —     | 16.8   | 20.0    |

*9M 2025 net profit is for the first nine months only.

question: What are the main drivers behind FAB’s growth strategy?
answer:
The main drivers behind FAB’s growth strategy are:

- **Diversified Revenue Streams & Business Mix**: We focus on accelerating growth and diversifying our business mix to unlock new revenue streams. This includes broad-based growth across Investment Banking & Markets, Wholesale Banking, and Personal, Business, Wealth & Privileged Client Banking, with strong performance in both funded and non-funded income segments<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>3</sup>.
- **International Expansion & Connectivity**: Our international franchise is a key contributor, with loans and deposits in international markets rising 23% and 18% year-to-date, respectively. We continue to expand our presence in over 20 global markets, reinforcing our position as a leading corridor bank for cross-border capital, trade, and investment flows. Recent milestones include new offices in Nigeria and Turkey, a branch in India, and plans for subsidiarisation in France<sup>2</sup><sup>4</sup>.
- **Client-Centric Innovation & Digitisation**: We are embedding advanced AI and digital solutions across our operations, such as Agentic AI, Board AI Observer, and GenAI-powered client servicing tools. This enhances efficiency, enables zero-touch customer experiences, and supports smarter, data-driven decision-making. Over 96% of our transactions are now conducted digitally<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup><sup>5</sup>.
- **Sustainability Leadership**: We are committed to embedding ESG factors in our culture and business strategies, with a target to facilitate AED 500 billion in sustainable and transition financing by 2030. To date, we have achieved 65% of this target, supporting both the UAE’s and our clients’ sustainability ambitions<sup>2</sup><sup>6</sup>.
- **Strong Balance Sheet & Risk Management**: Our robust capital, liquidity, and funding buffers, combined with disciplined risk management, provide a solid foundation for sustainable growth and resilience through changing market conditions<sup>1</sup><sup>2</sup>.
- **Alignment with UAE & Regional Growth**: As the UAE’s global bank, our strategy is closely aligned with the country’s economic diversification and growth agenda, enabling us to capture opportunities in both our home market and internationally<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.

References:  
<sup>1</sup> [Q2 2025 PR p. 3](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1708#page=3)  
<sup>2</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis Q3 2025 p. 4](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=4)  
<sup>3</sup> [Annual Report 2024 p. 13](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/436#page=13)

question: How is FAB leveraging AI and digital innovation to drive growth?
answer:
We are leveraging AI and digital innovation as a core driver of FAB’s growth and transformation, with tangible results across the Group:

- Embedded AI in operations and client service: We’ve rolled out our foundational Agentic AI platform, deployed Microsoft 365 Copilot to all employees, and launched AI-powered onboarding and credit analytics, leading to measurable improvements in efficiency and service quality. Innovations like the Board AI Observer, Voice Concierge, and planning tools are already delivering real impact<sup>1</sup>.
- Advanced analytics and automation: We are embedding intelligence in every decision with powerful analytical tools, such as the Board AI Observer, trade document validation, and distribution channels optimiser, enabling faster, data-informed decisions across the organisation<sup>2</sup>.
- AI-powered customer experience: GenAI tools like Voice Concierge, intelligent email routing, and real-time fraud detection are redefining customer service, delivering seamless, zero-touch experiences<sup>2</sup>.
- Strategic partnerships and innovation hubs: Our AI Innovation Hub, launched in partnership with Microsoft, accelerates the adoption of generative AI, intelligent automation, and machine learning. The hub focuses on product enhancement, personalisation, unique AI risk models, and new solutions for banking, including Banking-as-a-Service and Risk-as-a-Service<sup>3</sup><sup>4</sup>.
- End-to-end digitalisation: 96% of all transactions are now conducted digitally, and we’ve seen a 46% increase in digital transactions. Over 96% of service requests are processed digitally, supported by our market-leading, digitally driven service model<sup>5</sup><sup>6</sup>.
- Cloud and infrastructure modernisation: We are migrating workloads and data centres to Microsoft Azure and adopting cloud technology to enhance scalability, efficiency, and security. Our modernisation journey is guided by a five-year roadmap, ensuring business and technology priorities are aligned<sup>7</sup><sup>8</sup>.
- Open API and blockchain: We’ve upgraded our API infrastructure to support integration with emerging technologies like AI and blockchain, positioning FAB as a leader in open finance adoption across the UAE<sup>8</sup>.
- Internal innovation and fintech ecosystem: Our Research and Innovation Centre (FABRIC) drives the exploration and pilot testing of blockchain, crypto, and fintech partnerships, and identifies new digital growth opportunities<sup>9</sup>.

These initiatives are already unlocking measurable value, transforming how we operate, and supporting our strategy to deliver sustainable growth, operational excellence, and exceptional customer experiences.

question: What is the outlook for your non-funded income line this Q3 2025? Can we expect it to be 60% repeatable as communicated previously?
answer:
Our outlook for non-funded income (NFI) in Q3 2025 remains strong, with continued structural growth and a high degree of repeatability:

- Non-interest income surged 37% year-on-year to AED 12.70 billion for the first nine months of 2025, now contributing 46% of Group revenue<sup>1</sup>.
- Management has consistently communicated that approximately 60% of our non-funded income is considered "sticky and repeatable." This estimate was reiterated as recently as Q2 2025, and there is no indication of a change in this assessment for Q3 2025<sup>2</sup>.
- The underlying drivers—robust fee and commission growth, strong trading and investment performance, and healthy client flows—continue to support the sustainability of this income stream<sup>2</sup>.
- We remain focused on further diversifying and scaling our NFI base, with ongoing momentum in global markets, wealth, and asset management expected to provide additional tailwinds<sup>3</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Management Discussion & Analysis p. 2-6](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/3039#page=2)

<sup>3</sup> [Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript p. 17](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1829#page=17)

question: What is the outlook for your non-funded income line? Can we expect it to be 60% repeatable as communicated previously?
answer:
Our outlook for non-funded income remains very positive, with continued strong growth and a structurally higher contribution to total revenue. Here’s a summary of the latest trends and repeatability guidance:

- Non-funded income accounted for 46% of total revenue in the first half of 2025, up from 43% in Q1 and 38% in the prior year period<sup>1</sup>.
- Non-interest income rose 41% year-on-year in H1 2025 to AED 8.35 billion, with broad-based strength across all income lines. Fees and commissions grew 25% and FX/investment income rose 30% year-on-year, reflecting robust client flows and strong trading performance<sup>2</sup>.
- Management continues to estimate that around 60% of this non-funded income stream is “sticky and repeatable,” consistent with previous communications. This repeatability is supported by the scale and sophistication of our franchise, ongoing cross-sell opportunities, and the structural relevance of our global markets business<sup>2</sup>.
- The direction of travel is for non-funded income to increase relative to net interest income, with management targeting a sustainable split of around 45% non-funded income and 55% net interest income over time<sup>3</sup>.

References:

<sup>1</sup> [Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript p.7](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1829#page=7)  
<sup>2</sup> [Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript p.8](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1829#page=8)  
<sup>3</sup> [Q2 2025 Earnings Call Transcript p.17](https://wise-storage.euroland.com/api/pdf/download/1829#page=17)
